title: Open source and developer friendly load shedding calendar
description:
Being a South African means living through cycles upon cycles of power blackouts due to a highly inept public power utility known as Eskom. Needless to say their scheduling for which province, when and for how long load shedding will affect a place is not centralized. There are apps which private companies have developed in order to help the average South African citizen figure out when they will have no power and so on. This product, Eskom Se Push (named after a similarly sounding Afrikaans word I will not say in front of you all), is however closed source.

A friend of mine decided to create something similar but more along the lines of the UNIX philosophy by keeping it simple. No app is needed, just some iCal calendar files which will work across platforms and not just iOS or Android. He put quite a lot of effort into scraping the load shedding schedules from various municipalities, some manual work required too but the end results works rather well.

For more reading see:

  1. Eskom se Push: https://sepush.co.za/
  2. Load shedding (ZA and Ukraine): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rolling_blackout#South_Africa
  3. ZA Eskom: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_African_energy_crisis
  4. Article on Boyd‚Äôs open source load shedding calendar: http://www.sun.ac.za/english/Lists/news/DispForm.aspx?ID=9471
description_plain:
Being a South African means living through cycles upon cycles of power blackouts due to a highly inept public power utility known as Eskom. Needless to say their scheduling for which province, when and for how long load shedding will affect a place is not centralized. There are apps which private companies have developed in order to help the average South African citizen figure out when they will have no power and so on. This product, Eskom Se Push (named after a similarly sounding Afrikaans word I will not say in front of you all), is however closed source.

A friend of mine decided to create something similar but more along the lines of the UNIX philosophy by keeping it simple. No app is needed, just some iCal calendar files which will work across platforms and not just iOS or Android. He put quite a lot of effort into scraping the load shedding schedules from various municipalities, some manual work required too but the end results works rather well.

For more reading see:

1. Eskom se Push: https://sepush.co.za/
2. Load shedding (ZA and Ukraine): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rolling_blackout#South_Africa
3. ZA Eskom: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_African_energy_crisis
4. Article on Boyd's open source load shedding calendar: http://www.sun.ac.za/english/Lists/news/DispForm.aspx?ID=9471

submitter_user.about:
I‚Äôm Tristan B. Kildaire (or deavmi on the Internet) and I‚Äôm a computer programmer. I love tinkering around with all the bits of software that my computer runs but typically more on the low-level sides of things. I‚Äôm really interested in how operating systems work as a whole and their components such as kernels, networking stacks, linking-loaders, IPC, paging, virtual memory, file-systems and the list goes on. There‚Äôs so much to learn from understanding these complex systems and each aspect of them never leaves me bored!

You could call me a language enthusiast, from the design to the implementation. I always want to know how things work and I‚Äôve even spent time reading the source code for some language runtimes to get a better understanding. If I am feeling creative then I try write my own or write something in Forth! I love building networks too - I have an interest in setting up inter-networks with routing protocols, assigning numbers and setting up tunnels in order to build a huge network that I can play around on. When I‚Äôm not using other peoples' protocols I am busy writing my own to see what I can cobble out to itch my scratch on trying interesting concepts out.

I like a good glass of red wine and cheese. I have an avid enjoyment for music from the 70s and the 80s and have rather interesting political views (nothing to be alarmed of) but most importantly I like to help others learn and put a smile on their face.
